intro: Brassica oleracea var. opsibotrys, commonly known as the Chinese kale or neep, is a leafy vegetable characterized by its curly, dark green leaves and thick, edible stalks. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes other cruciferous vegetables like broccoli and cabbage. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with a rosette of leaves that are often used in Asian cuisines. Its botanical features include a fibrous root system and small, yellow flowers that appear in the spring. The plant is well adapted to temperate climates and thrives in well-drained soil.
